results.title: Hardy Heating Co.Ltd.: the accountant - the information manager
results.brief_description: SUMMARY: Introduction by Graham Turner. Looks at the role of the accountant in a relatively small company where he has to be both financial and management accountant. The aim of the program is to show the role and the managerial position of an accountant

results.title: Hardwoods of Papua New Guinea
results.creator_credit: Bruce Moir, Don Murray and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The film surveys timber developments showing logging, milling, paper-pulp making, and chip mills. Also shown is the work of the Forest Products Research Centre which provides technological assistance and re-afforestation [sic] programs.

results.title: Hard oil! How the Canadians discovered oil
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Kendall, Brian Arnott, David Springbett, Don Hopkins and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: The story of the early Canadian oil industry from its start in Petrolia and Oil Springs, Ontario, from about 1850 to 1900. Dramatic re-creations blend with archival photographs and diaries to tell the rags-to-riches-to-rags tale of a boom that went bust. Voice and narration by Max Ferguson, Allan McFee.

results.title: Hard knocks
results.creator_credit: Don McLennan, Hilton Bonner and Andromeda Productions
results.brief_description: A young girl, with a background of urban poverty and juvenile crime, attempts to become a fashion model. The hypocrisy and double standards of society are juxtaposed against the confusion and frustration she feels as she struggles to become part of a community that has no place for her.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don McLennan, Hilton Bonner and Andromeda Productions

results.title: Happy owls
results.creator_credit: Gene Deitch, Morton Schindel, W. Snyder and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: A pair of owls live happily together in an old ruin. One of the birds from a neighbouring farm, a peacock, observes their happiness and wonders at this achievement, as the birds he lives with are always squabbling and discontented. When the ducks, chicks and geese have congregated together the owls tell them a story illustrating the secret of their happiness. Unfortunately the birds refuse to believe or to learn. Based on the book by Celestino Piatti.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gene Deitch, Morton Schindel, W. Snyder and Weston Woods Studios

results.title: Happy little Vegemites = Cheap rush
results.creator_credit: Colin Mowbray, Dead Head Films and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: A furiously energetic short film about young homeless people who spend a night in emergency accommodation. They are bored and decide to search for some speed. When their efforts prove fruitless one of them decides that maybe a dose of vegemite might to the trick! With an excellent young cast and tight scripting, “Happy Little Vegemites” manages to be both comic, and in the scenes between the naive Gerard and the streetwise Chad, effectively touching. Features an excellent music track including Radiohead, Beasts of Bourbon and Rebecca’s Empire. Be warned, vegemite may never look the same again!

results.title: Happily unmarried
results.creator_credit: Anne Wheeler, Lorna Rasmussen, Tom Radford and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Joyce Rasmussen and her 25-year-old daughter Lorna have both chosen to live without partners. Joyce is divorced; Lorna has chosen to remain single. But they are friends and they talk openly about coping as “singles” in this couple-oriented society, and about their attitudes on such issues as monogamy and collective households.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Anne Wheeler, Lorna Rasmussen, Tom Radford and ONF | NFB

results.title: Hansel and Gretel by Engelbert Humperdinck
results.creator_credit: Elijah Moshinsky, Virginia Lumsden, ABC-TV (Australia) and Opera Australia
results.brief_description: Based on the Brothers Grimm fairytale, Englebert Humperdinck’s opera adaptation of “Hansel and Gretel” is for both adults and children alike. This fantastic Opera Australia production of the story provides a strong visual interpretation of the opera, with wonderfully surreal sets designed by Mark Thompson. Performers include: Suzanne Johnston, Christine Douglas, Elizabeth Campbell, Malcolm Donnelly, Gail Robertson. The Australian Opera (Australia) conducted by Johannes Fritzch. Staged by Elijah Moshinsky. Sung in English Translation.

results.title: Hansel and Gretel
results.creator_credit: John Paul, Michael Myerberg and Hansel and Gretel Co
results.brief_description: Children will love this adaptation of the famous Grimm fairy tale featuring life like marionettes (called Kinemins), authentic scenery and a musical soundtrack by Engelbert Humperdinck. Two children explore the forest in search of strawberries but are caught by the wicked witch who has a nasty habit of turning children into gingerbread. The original play was written by Adelaide Witty and adapted for the screen by Padraic Colum. Warning; The image drops out after the copyright warning but reappears before the video begins.

results.title: Hans Richter: early works
results.creator_credit: Hans Richter, Cecile Starr and Re:Voir
results.brief_description: Hans Richter was a German born artist. His broad and influential position in the art world saw him connected with many movements including the Blue Rider, Cubism, De Stijl, Expressionism, Constructivism, Surrealism and most notably Dada. Richter was a painter, graphic designer and filmmaker. The pieces included in his early works on film mixes both painting and cinematography ideas placing them side by side. The organised movement of his works where space, surface and line are rhythmically arranged make use of pure visual perception. His more illustrative works see many surrealist symbols and the use of the everyday inanimate object. Familiar symbols such as eyeballs, beards, clocks and trains are used. The use of nonsense and repetition combined with film processing techniques such as multiple exposure and layering of negative and positive footage are composed to create a sense of movement and rhythm. These short exciting experimental films certainly attest to Richter’s pivotal role in the development of early twentieth century avant-garde.
